Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Visible/Near-Infrared Sub-diffraction Imaging of DNA Walkers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Choi, Jong Hyun
1512537

The goal of this proposal is to develop a novel super-resolution scheme capable of simultaneous imaging in the visible and near-infrared range, and to use it for studying synthetic DNA walkers. DNA walkers are a class of nucleic acid and nanomachines that exhibit directional motion along a linear track. The proposed imaging strategy will be explored as a super-resolved bioanalytical platform to study single DNA motors.

Current sub-diffraction imaging methods uses a spectral range up to ~900 nm, thus failing to exploit 0.9-1.4 micron window, the so-called near-infrared IIa (NIR-IIa) biological window where the photon penetration depth into biological substances is the greatest due to minimal scattering and autofluorescence. The ability to use this spectral window would open up new opportunities to obtain and transfer the information about thick biological materials. Multicolor sub-diffraction imaging will visualize a DNA walker that transports inorganic cargo particles (e.g. CdTe/CdS core-shell nanocrystal quantum dots) along a carbon nanotube track. The visible fluorescence emission of the nanoparticles will be used to locate the DNA walkers along the immobilized individual carbon nanotubes that fluoresce in the NIR-II range. The proposed program will couple the research efforts with educational and outreach activities designed to advance the public understanding of biophotonics. The effort includes active involvement of undergraduate students in multidisciplinary research. They will actively recruit female and underrepresented students at individual and institutional levels via collaboration with Women in Engineering and Minority Engineering Programs at Purdue University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Super-resolved fluorescence microscopy transformed the field of single-molecule biophysics by providing new tools to probe molecular interactions and reaction kinetics with unprecedented resolution. This research program aimed at developing a new super-resolution scheme for optical imaging in the second near-infrared range for the first time. The second near-infrared spectrum ranges from 0.9 to 1.4 micrometers and is often considered biological optical window where the photon penetration depth into biological materials is greatest due to minimal scattering and autofluorescence. In this research, the new subdiffraction microscopy was used to characterize DNA-based synthetic molecular motors, resolving the walker structure and reaction rates. The stochastic nature of the walker kinetics was elucidated, and the information was used to develop general principles for designing highly efficient synthetic motors. The outcome of this research makes a transformative impact on a wide range of areas from fundamental sciences such as biophysics and chemistry to engineering applications including biological and medical imaging.

 

The project activities included strong efforts integrating cutting-edge research with education and outreach. The research team implemented a hands-on outreach module to advance the public understanding of optical microscopy and biomolecular nanotechnology. This project engaged a faculty investigator, 1 postdoctoral scholar, 5 graduate researchers, and several undergraduate students who together published 1 book chapter and 10 journal papers. This program provided a unique research environment where students were exposed to diverse disciplines and learned from each other, becoming competent engineers and scientists of next generation.
